docs.lead_paragraph: Fred Koehler is such a natural in ''When I Was a Girl, I Used to Scream and Shout'' you forget now and then that the play is not about him. As the title broadly suggests, the comedy-drama, by the Scottish writer Sharman Macdonald, is, among other things, a bittersweet look back at the turmoil in the life of a confused teen-age girl. But Mr. Koehler, playing Ewan, a drifting young slacker unimpressed by any satisfaction of life that doesn't involve the physical, draws disproportionate attention to Ewan's plight with a canny, effortlessly honest performance. It's endearing in spite of itself.
docs.abstract: Peter Marks reviews Sharman Macdonald's play, When I Was a Girl, I Used to Scream and Shout, directed by Patricia Minskoff and presented by John Montgomery Theater Company; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan Through Thursday This wide-ranging selection of works proposes that the orb is one of the archetypal motifs of modern art. Associated with the egg and the eye, it suggests concentration, pregnancy and transcendental mystery. By contrast, another archetypal modern motif, the grid, reflects the architectural fabric of modernity and an infinitely extendable space of Cartesian rationality. In art, the grid tends to sponsor formalist tendencies; the orb often inspires Symbolism, Surrealism or primitivism. The show bears this out, including as it does a number of well-known artists associated with mystical romance, like Joseph Cornell, whose 1958 shadowbox contains a cork ball and a smiling Victorian sun against a white, empyrean beyond; Richard Pousette-Dart, in whose small abstract painting (1967) a haze of cosmic light radiates from a center of concentric circles, and Alfonso Ossorio, whose circular mixed-media assemblage (1967) of bones and glass eyeballs is like a scary fetish of some not fully civilized tribe.
docs.abstract: Ken Johnson reviews Essence of the Orb, wide-ranging selection of works at Michael Rosenfeld Gallery (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of babies who died before their first birthday continued to fall in New York City last year -- though not in all neighborhoods -- in a decline health officials say reflects less drug use, better prenatal care and fewer pregnancies among teen-agers. Statistics released yesterday by the City Health Department show that New York's infant mortality rate is now roughly identical to the national rate, which has historically been far lower than New York's. In 1997, the new numbers show, there were 7.1 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in New York City, compared with 7.8 the year before. Nationally in 1996, the last year for which data are available, the rate was 7.2 deaths.

headline.main: Infant Mortality Falls Again, In Step With Rate Nationwide

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Monitoring Efforts Fail to Stop Baby Switching'' (news article, Aug. 5): Here's an idea to prevent the unfortunate consequences of inadvertently or intentionally switching babies at birth. What if mothers and healthy full-term infants were never separated?

docs.lead_paragraph: How could I not be glad to know my birth?'' So says Oedipus, in the 2,500-year-old play, still unaware of the terrible revelation to come: that his parents were not the people who had raised him. Well, past and present came together in a big way last week in a modern variation of the old story, as two families learned that their children, Rebecca Grace Chittum and Callie Marie Johnson, had been switched at birth.
docs.abstract: Janna Malamud Smith Op-Ed article on poignant story of Rebecca Chittum and Callie Marie Johnson, toddlers who were switched shortly after they were born in Virginia hospital three years ago (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: BANKRUPT and battered in a time of managed health care and hospital mergers, Mid-Island Hospital in Bethpage had been looking in vain for ways to stay afloat. Then along came two large Long Island-based health providers, Catholic Health Services of Long Island and Winthrop South Nassau University Health System, with a takeover offer that would save Mid-Island's 350 jobs and shore up its treatment programs.

headline.main: Saving Hospitals, But Not All Their Parts
